Ella posee una tienda en la cual vende productos de primera necesidad, a pesar que cuenta con mucha competencia, Roxana no pierde la esperanza de poder mejorar las condiciones de su negocio, ya que ella cuenta con la necesidad de mejorar su economía familiar y poder brindarles todo lo necesario a sus hijas. Es por esto que ella solicita un préstamo a través del cual pueda comprar más productos de primera necesidad, de manera que logre surtir en lo más posible la tienda y de esta manera ser la primera opción para todas las personas del lugar.
texts.en:
Roxana A. M., 33, lives in Ilopango with her husband, who is a pick-up driver, that makes trips towards Lake Ilopango. She has two, minor daughters, who are in schools. She has a grocery store where she sells basic needs items. Despite having a lot of competition, Roxana doesn't lose hope of being able to improve her business's condition because she needs to improve her family's economic situation to provide her daughters with all they need. For this reason, she is requesting funding to buy more stock items so that her store will be more productive and become the first choice for shoppers in her area.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy basic needs items.

loans.name: Annielice's Group

texts.en: Annielice R. is from the village of Punit, Benito Soliven, Isabela. She is 56 years old and is the group leader of a four-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Annielice R.' Group. Annielice is married and has two school-aged children. She owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling eggs in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over twenty-three years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. In 2009, Annielice joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Annielice is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her second from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: The Womens Bank To Build The Future Group

texts.en:
This group’s name translates as “The Womens Bank to Build the Future”. The group members live in Sarapiqui, Heredia, a rural region close to the Caribbean coast of Costa Rica. The group members will use this loan for general investments in productive activities such as the rearing and selling of chickens and the purchase and sale of colognes and perfumes.

Christina A. V. is the president of this group. She is always busy and engages in many economically productive activities such as curtain sewing, nail painting, selling retail products and poultry. This loan will be used for the purchase of chicks as well as feed for the rearing and sale of her poultry.

Christina aspires to open a store one day where she can offer a range of services and products to her clients. She says her only obstacle is financial and that she works with her husband as a team: when Christina needs to work, her husband watches their daughter and vice versa (he is a taxi driver and farmer).

Dinia Gisselle G. G. is a 33-year-old mother who lives with her family in Sarapiqui. She has a business selling men’s and women’s colognes and perfumes in her community. She started her business with an initial investment of 100,000 colons. Her husband´s work requires him to travel to Panama roughly every fifteen days. In Panama the prices for quality perfume and cologne products is much less than in Sarapiqui. For example, a name brand perfume that sells for 12,000 colons in Panama sells for 22,000 colons in Sarapiqui.

Dinia has been selling perfumes and colognes for five years. She spends her days traveling to homes and restaurants in Sarapiqui, offering products to potential clients. She collects orders from her clients which she passes on to her husband who makes the necessary purchases when he arrives in Panama. Dinia says her business is growing; she wants to expand operations as the income she earns contributes significantly to her family’s standard of living.

Dinia knows that she faces much competition in her community; there are many women selling similar products. As a result, she strives to provide superior service to her clients by bringing them all the products they request.

Sometimes, Dinia’s clients have trouble paying for an item in full. In these cases Dinia organizes flexible payment schedules to suit the needs of her client. She hopes to one day open a store where she could sell not only perfumes and colognes, but clothing and cosmetics as well.

Dinia hopes that “The Womens Bank to Build the Future” will expand and acquire more members from the community.

loans.use: To purchase chicks and poultry feed

loans.name: Ronard

texts.en: Ronard is the 43-year-old father of five children who are in school. He owns a welding and fabrication business in Nairobi and says he has been doing well in his business. He has requested his first loan of Kes. 30,000 to buy a place to display his wares. He describes himself as a man of excellence and hopes to excel in business and get big contracts for his welding business.

loans.use: Buy a place to display his wares

loans.name: Fadi

texts.en:
Fadi is a 33-year-old married man with 3 young children. He has been working as a taxi driver since 1998, servicing his town and its surroundings. In addition, he offers private transportation services upon request of his clients. He is always trying to work long hours to earn enough income to be able to pay for his children's school fees. 

Fadi has requested a loan of $1,000 to carry out maintenance work on his car. He wants to increase its safety features and offer comfortable transportation to his customers.

loans.use: To carry out maintenance work on his car

loans.name: Asca Bekyibei

texts.en:
Asca T., 56, is married and the mother of seven lovely children. She lives in Kipsangui, Eldoret area. She owns a ten acre plot where she plants maize for resale. Most of her customers are her neighbors. She has been in the farming business for three years now, however, she also sells milk and passion fruits. 

Asca was introduced to KADET by an existing client. She has applied for a loan which she will use to buy fertilizers and maize seedlings. 

Asca's immediate goal is to buy another ten acre plot of land to increase her production and, therefore, get more income with which to feed her family.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and maize seedlings.

loans.name: Narcisa

texts.en:
Narcisa B., from the village of Upper Lamac Oroquieta City, is 48 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Narcisa owns and operates a business venture in the food sector making and selling snacks and other delicacies such as rice cake and other foods in the local community. Engaged in her business for over two years, she earns approximately 1200 PHP a month.

In 2007, Narcisa joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from GDMPC, she is now requesting a new loan, her seventh, of 6000 PHP to further invest in her business. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in her business

loans.name: Los Unicos Group

texts.es:
El Banco de Emprendimiento LOS UNICOS esta esta conformado 8 integrantes se encuentran en su primer ciclo, son nuevos todos viven en la misma zona en el barrio El Carmen, cuentan con negocio propio hace  dos años en el km 9 camino a Santa C..

La Sra. LIZETH es la presidenta dle banco fue elegida por su responsabilidad compañerismo y solidaridad que demostro en el trato a las socias, la Sra. Lizeth se dedica a la venta de cosmeticos por catalogo de una prestigios empresa a nivel Mundial, con el dinero del credito comprara cosmeticos que se  encuentran en promocion, las revistas sacan productos en promocion que se encuentran mas baratos que el precio original y siguiente publicacion el producto que estaba mas barato, en la nueva publicacion esta mas caro, y asi ella obtiene una ganancia extra.
 

Las socias de este banco de emprendimiento en su gran mayoria son Padres de Familia y son personas muy luchadoras ellos tienen el sueño de que sus negocios engrandesca y ser muy exitosos, y asi poder mejorar la calidad de vida de toda su familia, ellos se encuentran agradecidos con la institucion por brindarles la confianza en la otorgacion del credito.
texts.en:
The venture bank group Los Unicos is comprised of eight members in their first cycle. They all live in the same neighborhood in El Carmen, nine kilometers from Santa C.. They have had their own business for two years. Lizeth is the president of the bank group. She was chosen for her responsibility, camaraderie, and solidarity, which she has demonstrated in her treatment of the other members. Lizeth sells catalog cosmetics from a prestigious worldwide company. With this loan, she will buy cosmetics on sale. The magazines promote products much cheaper than their original prices, and in subsequent publications the cheaper products become much more expensive, and this is how she makes an extra profit. The majority of the members of this venture bank group are heads of family and they are fighters. They dream that their businesses will expand and be very successful, and then they will be able to improve the quality of life for all their families. They are grateful to the institution for having the confidence in them to loan them credit.

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is 35 years old. He is married to a business lady and they have six children. He is a member of Tushauriane Self Help Group where he gets his loans guaranteed.

Charles has been operating a retail shop in Nairobi for two years as well as a barber shop. He says that since he joined Faulu Kenya he has been able to save money.

Charles has requested a loan of Kes 50,000 to add stock to his retail shop such as sugar, flour, cooking fat and other products. He describes himself as hardworking and hopes to grow his business into a wholesale operation.

loans.use: To add to his stock of sugar, flour and cooking fat

loans.name: Florita

texts.en:
Florita L. is a 68-year old married woman who lives in San Francisco, Santa Catalina, Negros Oriental. She earns her living by engaging in a fishing business.

Florita’s 40 year old husband, Lowim, owns and manages his own bakery business. They have 3 adult children. 

Florita joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1998 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD, she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in a fishing business. Now she earns an average monthly income of PHP20,000 from her business activities.

Florita is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of PHP19,000 was used to fund the operations of her fishing business, and it had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing for her 18th cycle loan, the amount of PHP19,000, which she intends to use on her fishing business. Florita is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital.

loans.name: Felicite

texts.en:
Felicite is 48 years old, married with 9 children who are between 7 and 28 years old.  Felicite is commonly known in the business of selling Irish potatoes, and she has been in this business for about three years.  Felicite starts her business from 7 am and goes to 4 pm every day.

After realizing her inefficiency at satisfying the demand of her customers, Felicite is requesting a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company.  With this loan, Felicite will hopefully earn more profit and this profit will allow her to reinvest more in her business.  Through the earned profits, Felicite will also start saving for her future as well as improving the lifestyle of her family.

loans.use: buying a large quantity of Irish potatoes

loans.name: Mazalou

texts.fr: G. mazalo est une femme mariée et mère de 3 enfants, elle vit avec sa famille dans le quartier de  sorad à Lomé. Son époux est un chauffeur. Depuis 2003 elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de sacs de charbons de bois. Elle s’approvisionne au nord du Togo car la bas le sac de charbon de bois est moins coûteux. Elle fait son commerce à la devanture de sa maison. Son stock est en baisse elle veut le rehausser et elle demande donc son deuxième prêt à WAGES afin de s’acheter  30 sacs de charbons de bois et assurer le transport de la marchandise.
texts.en:
Mazalo G. is married and has three children. She lives with her family in the Sorad neighborhood of Lome. Her husband is a driver. Since 2003 she has made her living selling charcoal. She buys it in northern Togo where it is cheaper. She sells by the roadside in front of her house. Since her stock is low, she wants to rebuild it. That is why she is asking for a second loan from WAGES to buy 30 sacks of charcoal and to pay for its transportation.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy charcoal

loans.name: Josphat Kauria

texts.en:
Josphat Kauria Mpurunyuk is 28 years old. He is married to Joyce and the father of three school-going children. He is a farmer and has been farming on his own piece of land for the last five years.

He learned about KADET from other members in a group already registered with KADET in his community. This will be his first loan which he is planning to use to buy fertilizer and chemicals for his potato farm. Potatoes have been doing well in his area due to good climatic conditions. He hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand his farming activity from small scale to commercial farming.

Josphat's dreams are to do large scale farming and also to start dairy farming. He is a hard working man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and chemicals for his potato farm

loans.name: Romel

texts.es: Romel solicito un  300 $us, para la compra de repuestos de movilidad.  y así  mejorar su servicio para con sus clientes, ya que por el constante uso  su minibús presenta fallas mecánicas; su esposa se dedica al cuidado de su hijo. Es el primer crédito en impro y el primero vía Kiva. La familia vive en la ciudad de La Paz.
texts.en:
Romel requests a loan of $300 US to purchase spare parts for his minibus, so that he will improve service to his clients. He is in constant use of the minibus and it is showing some mechanical problems. His wife is dedicated to the care of their son. This is his first loan with Impro (Kiva Field Partner). The family lives in the city of La Paz.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To carry out maintenance repairs to his minibus.

loans.name: Jeanette

texts.en:
This is Jeanette S., a 41-year-old resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Precilo S., a mason. She is the mother of four children, one of whom is already working while the other three are still in school, one in college and the other two in high school. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send her remaining children all the way through college - a dream for most Filipino parents like Jeanette as she herself was an elementary graduate and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Jeanette operates a rug-making business. She mainly offers rugs, from those round, palm-sized ones to the much larger doormats, braided quilts and bed sheets, and other crafts that most rug-makers come up with every day. As rugs are a major part of Filipino housekeeping and cleaning, rugs are one of the most common products that can be bought, sometimes even from a peddler while you are riding in a speeding jeepney down the highway. Besides rugs, Jeanette also retails bulk charcoal to her neighbors to be used as fuel for old-fashioned stoves. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 300 Philippine pesos (Php) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php12,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread and newspapers for patterns. She will also invest a portion of the loan to bulk buy sacks of charcoal to be repackaged and sold. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Jeanette dreams to be able to give her all her children a good and high-quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: Buy more quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread and newspapers for patterns. She will also invest a portion of the loan to bulk buy sacks of charcoal to be repackaged and sold.

loans.name: Noe

texts.es: El señor Noe trabaja en una Maquiladora de la localidad y su esposa la señora Mayra, trabaja como empleada domestica en una casa habitación. Ellos tienen dos hijos pequeños. El señor Noe adquirió una vivienda de interés social y el motivo por el cual están solicitando este crédito es por que quieren ampliar el baño para la mejor comodidad de su familia.
texts.en:
Noe works in a factory in his region and his wife Mayra works in the private home cleaning industry. They have two small children. Noe was given a house from community housing and the reason he requests a loan is to improve their bathroom, for the family's greater comfort.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To build a bathroom.

loans.name: Mariana De Jesus

texts.es:
Mariana de 37 años, es comerciante informal de ropa, vive con sus hijos de 16 y 14 años en una zona periurbana llamada Perimetral rodeada del estero salado de Guayaquil. 

Hace 6 años atrás su esposo solventaba la economía de su casa mientas que ella estudiaba y atendía a sus hijos, pero el falleció y ella tubo que hacerse cargo de los gastos de su familia vendiendo ropa. Desde ese tiempo hasta ahora vendiendo ropa como comerciante informal para poder mantener a sus hijos. las blusas las vende a $ 20.00, pantalones a $ 30.00 etc. 

Para seguir con su negocio de ropa ella quiere comprar con el préstamo ropa y otra parte dedicarla para mejorar su casa comprando cemento, bloques y pinturas.
texts.en:
Mariana, 37 years old, is an informal clothing merchant who lives with her children, ages 16 and 14, in an area called Perimetral, surrounded by Guayaquil's salt marsh. Some 6 years ago, her husband covered household expenses while she studied and cared for their children. But he died and she had to take charge of family costs by selling clothes. From that time until today, she has sold clothes as an informal merchant to be able to maintain her children. She sells blouses for $20, pants for $30, etc. To continue with her clothing business, she wishes, with this loan, to buy clothes to sell, and also, to buy materials to improve her house, including cement, blocks, and paint.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING CEMENT AND PAINT FOR HER HOUSE AND CLOTHING TO SELL

loans.name: Señor Cautivo De Ayabaca Group

texts.es: La señora Nancy tiene 37 años y vive en la zona “F”, es soltera y tiene 3 hijos de los cuales aun tiene a cargo a uno, es presidenta del Grupo: “Señor Cautivo de Ayabaca”  que está conformado por 10 vecinas y llevan 4 años trabajando con Edaprospo. Nancy tiene una bodega en la que vende productos de primera necesidad como arroz, fideos, conservas y bebidas, comenzó desde hace tres años vendiendo queso y carne y poco ah poco lo ah ido implementando, con su esfuerzo y la ayuda de capital de Edaprospo ah comprado su propio terreno y mantenido su hogar, además de pagar los estudios de su hijo. En el futuro espera agrandar su negocio y poner una distribuidora de cerveza para mejorar la vida de su familia y comenzar la construcción de su casa, pero para esto necesita que Edaprospo le brinde más habilitaciones.
texts.en: Nancy is 37 years old and she lives in Zone F. She is single and she has 3 children, though only one is still in her care. She is the leader of the group named Senor Cautivo de Ayacaba. The group is made up of 10 neighbors that have worked for the past 4 years with Edaprospo (Kiva Field Partner). Nancy has a grocery store where she sells every day products such as rice, pasta, jams, and soft drinks. With a great deal of effort and with a capital fund loan from Edaprospo she has been able to purchase a plot of land and she has supported her family. She has also managed to pay the tuition expenses for her son. In the future she hopes to expand her business and set up a beer distribution company. She will improve the quality of life for her family and she will be able to start building a house for herself. But she will need continued support from Edaprospo to reach these goals.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Gereltsogt

texts.en:
Gereltsogt H. is a 34 year old widower who lives with his 8 year old daughter in Uvs province of Mongolia. He and his daughter live in a ger, a traditional Mongolian home tent. His wife passed away 3 years ago. The family had been happily living in the countryside, leading a nomadic lifestyle, until the tragic incident happened to his family.

After that, he sold all his livestock and moved to his current town. He began his taxi service in 2007, after purchasing a new car, and has built a stable operation over the years. Gereltsogt earns a monthly average profit of 180,000 MNT. With his earning, he was able to start building a house for his family. He works hard to finish construction of his house by next year. He is a very modest man and is requesting a 1,500,000 MNT loan to purchase winter tires for his car and necessary materials for his house, which is under construction.

loans.use: To purchase winter tires and materials.

loans.name: Perlita

texts.en:
Perlita S. is from Molicay, Ozamiz City. She is 45 years old. Perlita is married and has 2 children. To make a living, Perlita owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting & harvesting  a variety of vegetables for sale. Perlita has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Perlita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Perlita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from GDMPC. Perlita is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Perlita from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: El Gran Esfuerzo 4 Group

texts.es:
Rosa es una de los miembros del Grupo El Gran Esfuerzo, localizado en La ciudad de Hato Mayor, cuya economia depende de la agricultura y es una de las ciudades mas rurales de República Dominicana, en donde como muchas hay escasez de agua potable y de energía electrica y con una poblacion de dominicanos y emigrantes haitianos. Sus actividades principales son las ventas de ropas. Rosa es madre de 1 hijo, y viven junto a ella y su padre. Nos dice que su reto o desafío más difícil son seguir trabajando duro para poder estar tranquila y descansar cuando cumpla mas años y tambien poder ayudar a sus hijos. Le encanta asistir a la Iglesia.

Rosa está muy emocionada de recibir su Decimo préstamo en Esperanza Internacional, después de haber pagado satisfactoriamente su préstamos anteriores y asi haber dado un paso para el crecimiento de su negocio. Ella ha tenido su negocio por alrededor de 10 años, el cual inició con un pequeño ahorro, que guardaba para fines de negocio. Está planificando invertir su nuevo préstamo en la compra de diferentes modelos y estilos de ropa. Planea utilizar sus ganancias para comprar cosas que necesita y hacer mejoras en su vivienda.
texts.en:
Rosa is one of the members of 'El Gran Esfuerzo' (The Big Effort) group which is located in the town of Hato Mayor.  The town's economy depends on farming and it is one of the most rural towns in the Dominican Republic.  As in many other towns, there is a scarcity of drinking water and electricity and a population of Dominicans and emigrant Haitians.  The group's main business activity is selling clothes.

Rosa has one child and they live together with her father.  She tells us that her greatest challenges are to continue working hard so that she can be relaxed and rest when she is older, and also to help her children.  She loves going to church.

Rosa is very excited to be receiving her tenth loan from Esperanza Internacional, after having satisfactorily paid off her previous loans and thereby given a step forward in the growth of her business.  She has had her business for around 10 years.  She set up her business with a small amount of savings which she was keeping for business purposes.  She is planning to invest her new loan in buying different styles of clothes.  She plans to use her profits to buy things which she needs and make improvements to her home.

loans.use: To buy clothes

loans.name: Inda

texts.en:
Inda I. is a married woman who lives in Tagdalungon, Brgy. Rio-Tuba, Bataraza, Palawan. She earns her living by operating 2 business ventures:  dried fish selling and food vending.  Her husband Abdurahman I., who is 57 years old, works as a fisherman to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities.  They have 6 children who are 10 to 25 years old. 

Inda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 13 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Inda has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. 

Her previous loan of PHP 19,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, thus uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 14th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 22,000 which she intends to use as additional capital for food processing so that she can continue to save up for future home repairs and the education of her children. Inda I. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path towards the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.  Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To fund operations of dried fish business

loans.name: Ferdinand

texts.en:
Ferdinand V. is from the village of Benito, Soliven, Isabela. He is 36 years old. Ferdinand is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Ferdinand owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting & harvesting corn for sale. Ferdinand has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 32,000 PHP per harvest.

In 2010, Ferdinand joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ferdinand has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. Ferdinand is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Ferdinand from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business. 

About the Kiva's Field Partner, ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is 42 years old and married with three school-aged children who all attend school. He is a farmer from Murang'a town in central Kenya where he has been farming for 20 years and employs five farmhands. His mixed farm produces coffee, horticultural products and milk which he sells to the local market and through Kenya Co-operative Creameries. He depends solely on the income from his farming activities to cater for his family's basic needs.

He has requested this loan of 53,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. The extra income from this loan will help improve his family's livelihood. He faces the challenge of a lack of veterinary services. He hopes to acquire five more high-yielding dairy cows in future.

loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Merha May

texts.en:
Merha May S. is from the village of Gata Daku Clarin Misamis Occidental. She is 26 years old. Merha May is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Merha May owns & operates a business venture in the services sector operating transportation services. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from operating motor transport services. Merha May has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 30000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Merha May joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Merha May has successfully repaid a previous loan  from GDMPC. Merha May is requesting a new loan of 50000 PHP which will be used to repair her motorcycle to provide better service. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Merha May from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to repair an existing vehicle to provide better service

loans.name: Khaled

texts.ar:
خالد في عمر 37 سنة متزوج وله 5 اولاد يعمل في محل لبيع خردوات السيارات له في عمله 15 سنة يحب عمله ويريد تطويره
يسعى وراء لقمة العيش وتحسين وضع اولاده وتطوير نفسه في المجتمع يتميز بالتوسع في العمل حيث انك تلقى لديه جميع قطع السيارات
يريد طلب قرض من المجموعة بهدف توسيع المحل وتركيب استندات + سقف للمحل بهدف زيادة الخردوات في المحل
texts.en: Khaled, 37, is married with 5 children. He works at a shop that sells auto accessories. He likes his business, where he has been working for 15 years. He works hard to earn his living, in order to improve his own status as well as his children's in society. He works in various types of auto accessories. Khaled wants to get a loan from A. Majmoua to expand his shop and install a roof as well as shelves so that he can increase his products.

loans.use: Install a roof and shelves for his shop

loans.name: Guillermina

texts.en: Guillermina is 60 years old, married, and has seven children who are all in school. She is using her loan of 1,500 PEN towards the construction of a new house. She is a member of the communal bank "Kausachun" and has been with FINCA Peru for one year, after being introduced by her sister. She has used past loans to purchase grocery products to sell in her store in Pueblo Sucre, several hours outsiD. of Ayacucho.

loans.use: Construction materials for a new house

loans.name: Felicita

texts.es: Felicita H. de 65 años de edad, reside en San Francisco Gotera, ubicado en el departamento de Morazán, ella es una mujer casada quien vive únicamente junto a su esposo. A su edad, Felicita debe esforzarse a diario por poder salir adelante, por lo que se dedica a la venta de perfumes para hombres y mujeres, cremas y desodorantes, los cuales comercializa en su casa de habitación, y así mismo los comercializa de forma ambulante, con sus vecinos y amigos, entre los cuales ya cuenta con varios clientes fijos. Felicita solicita un préstamo a Integral con el enorme deseo de mejorar su negocio, surtiéndolo con cantidad de marcas de perfumes en diversidad de precios, de forma que pueda contar con un mercado más amplio y de esta manera aumentar sus ventas, lo cual es muy importante para ella.
texts.en:
65-year old Felicita H. lives in San Francisco Gotera which is located in Morazán department with her husband. Even at her age, Felicita makes an effort to make progress in life so she sells colognes and perfumes for men and women as well as lotions and deodorants from her home. She also goes house to house selling to neighbours and friends amongst whom she has many regular customers.

Felicita is seeking a loan from Kiva partner Apoyo Integral as she has a great desire to improve her business by stocking it with a range of brands at different prices. This way she would have a wider market and be able to increase sales--which is very important to her.

loans.use: purchase of more perfumes to sell

location.town: San Francisco Gotera, departamento de Morazán

loans.name: Eleloh

texts.en:
Eleloh is married and has 3 children, all of whom attend school. His wife operates a food stall and supports the upbringing of the children. Eleloh has been operating a butcher shop for the last 3 years; his local residents are his potential customers. 

With the loan he is requesting, Eleoh wants to start a barber shop business and purchase a hair-cutting machine to increase his monthly profits. Eleloh dreams of establishing a beauty salon in the future. He decided to work with Yehu because of its loan efficiency.

loans.use: to start a barber shop business and purchase a hair-cutting machine

loans.name: Rodrigo

texts.en:
Rodrigo S. Jr. is from the village of Santo Niño, Manolo Fortich, Bukidnon. He is 30 years old. Rodrigo is married and has an infant child. Rodrigo owns and operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing motorela or habal-habal (motorcycle transport) services to local community members. Rodrigo has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it.

In 2010, Rodrigo joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to do business. He has successfully repaid his last loan from HSPFI, which was for 5,000 PHP and was used to purchase tools needed to provide service.

This loan will be his second from HSPFI. Rodrigo is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to to purchase tools & utilities needed for the maintenance of the service. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand it.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase tools & utilities needed for the maintenance of the service

loans.name: Flora

texts.en: Flora is 28 years old, married, and has four children, all of whom go to school. She is currently in the business of selling fish. Flora has taken a loan to stock more fish to sell. She hopes to expand her business in the future with the extra profits from her business.

loans.use: to stock more fish to sell

loans.name: Najma

texts.en:
Najma is married and has one child. For the past two years, she has operated a clothes selling business, selling from her home to her neighbors and passersby. She sells lesos (kangas), the Kenyan women's attire wrapped around the waist. Najma faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She lives at a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is rent bills. She dreams of prospering in her business and building her own house. 

Najma is requesting a loans for 40,000 KES, which she will use to purchase bundles of lesos (kangas), cloth materials, and curtains. She joined Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of lesos (kangas), cloth materials, and curtains.

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites is 29 years old and is a married woman. She has two children aged 10 and 3. Her husband works as a farmer and security guard.

Marites is also a farmer. She helps her husband till their farm where they grow rice crops. According to Marites, their current earnings are about $150 per month. She does her best to keep their farm productive. She applied for a loan and plans to use it to purchase three sacks of seed and six sacks of fertilizers. Marites hopes for her family's living conditions to improve.

loans.use: to purchase 3 sacks of seeds and 6 sacks of fertilizers.

loans.name: Linda

texts.en:
35-year-old Linda earns a living through farming. She tills her own land where she grows rice crops to sell. She earns about $150 per month from doing this farming. Her loan will be used to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies.

Linda works hard to support her family. She has five children, the oldest of whom is only 12 years old. Linda hopes for her children to have bright futures.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and other farm supplies.

loans.name: Vladimer

texts.en:
Vladimer comes from the village of Martkopi, Gardabani District. He is married and lives with his wife Nina, son and mother. Nina works as a teacher in a local school. Vladimer’s son is a joiner and works in his own workshop. Vladimer has a minibus; he drives passengers on the Martkopi – Lilo line. This line is always crowded, because Lilo is a wholesale centre of East Georgia and people from Martkopi and nearby villages often travel there for shopping purposes. Recently, Vladimer’s minibus had some problems and he had to stop work. He needs to repair his minibus in order to continue provision of quality transportation services to villagers.
Vladimer has requested credit to repair his minibus, which is an important source of income for him and his family. A small part of the credit will be used to renovate part of his house.

loans.use: to pay for minibus repairs and materials for house renovation.

loans.name: Degnon Group

texts.fr: DEGNON est un groupe constitué de trois personnes et dont la  présidente (celle qui a la main levée sur la photo) se nomme Valérie. Les membres du groupe appartiennent à la même Eglise. Dans le but d’augmenter leur fonds de roulement, ce groupe sollicite pour la troisième fois, un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Valérie est née le 07 Avril 1972 au Bénin. Valérie est mariée à un menuisier du nom de Victorin. Le couple a deux enfants tous scolarisés et vivant ensemble avec eux. Après avoir arrêté l’école au cours secondaire, Valérie a commencer depuis treize ans, la vente de charbon de bois à son domicile. De façon secondaire, Valérie vend des biscuits. Valérie s'approvisionne dans l'un des marché du Bénin. Cette activité lui génère des revenus l'aidant à ainsi assurer les diverses charges de la famille. Ce troisième prêt permettra certainement à Valérie et aux autres membres du groupe DEGNON de rehausser le niveau de leur activité et d’accroître leur clientèle et leur revenu.
texts.en:
DEGNON is a group made up of three people whose president (the one who is raising her hand in the photo) is called Valérie. The members of the group belong to the same church. In order to grow their working capital, this group is asking for their third loan from ALIDé. 

Valérie was born on April 7, 1972 in Bénin. She is married to a carpenter named Victorin. The couple have two children, both enrolled in school, and live together with their children. Valérie began selling charcoal at her home 13 years ago. Secondarily, she sells cookies. She buys her supplies in a market in Bénin. This activity generates revenue that she uses to help support the family. This third loan will certainly permit Valérie and the other members of the group called DEGNON to expand their business and grow their clientele and their revenue.

loans.use: to buy sacks of charcoal.
